thread.title: Bagley's potential shows in BC win
thread.title_full: Bagley's potential shows in BC win

author: courier-journal.com
title: Bagley's potential shows in BC win
text:
It feels like it was ages ago when Louisville football coach Bobby Petrino raved about his new young receiver Javonte Bagley in training camp last year.
Petrino said Bagley, a former basketball star who found football in high school, reminded him a bit of Harry Douglas, who had back-to-back 1,000-yard seasons as a receiver during Petrino's first tenure at U of L.
It was a high compliment. But Bagley faded into the background once the season began, catching two passes in just four appearances. Then this fall, Louisville's new receivers -- Jaylen Smith, Ja'Quay Savage, Jamari Staples, Traveon Samuel and Devante Peete in particular -- got all the attention through the first half of the campaign.
Saturday's 17-14 win over Boston College put some of that spotlight back on Bagley, now a sophomore who says he has realized the value of practice. He caught three passes for 69 yards, including one grab that went for 39 yards.
THE COURIER-JOURNAL
Instant Analysis | Cards hold off BC
Smith's apparent arm injury left a void for Bagley to fill. And his hard work in practice, quarterback Lamar Jackson said, paid off in big ways. Only Staples, who had four catches for 96 yards, had more receptions or yards.
"It felt great to be able to get a chance to play," Bagley said. "I've been waiting for my chance."
Petrino said Bagley is still learning a game that is relatively new to him. It certainly didn't help that Bagley, who grew up in Vero Beach, Fla., played in a run-focused offense in his two years of high school ball.
But there's no denying the 6-foot-3, 192-pound wideout's potential, and Saturday's win showed what it looks like when Bagley puts it all together.
"It was great to see Bagley step in and make plays for us," Petrino said. "He's a guy who really didn't start playing football until he was a junior in high school. He's extremely talented, but he's kind of just learning the game. He keeps getting better. When Jaylen got hurt, it was great to see him come in and make plays for us."
